links.title: Kiwix
links.description: Offline reader for web content—download and browse entire websites like Wikipedia or Stack Overflow without Internet access.

links.title: Zotero
links.description: Free tool to collect, organize, cite, and share research, with strong offline capabilities and local libraries.

links.title: Project Gutenberg
links.description: Over 70,000 free eBooks you can download and store locally—great for reading and archival projects.

links.title: LibreOffice
links.description: Powerful open-source office suite—word processing, spreadsheets, presentations—all fully offline-capable.

links.title: Joplin
links.description: Markdown-based note-taking and to-do app with full offline sync and encryption support.

links.title: ArchiveBox
links.description: Self-hosted web archiving solution to collect, save, and browse URLs offline, including full HTML snapshots.

tips.title: Build a Self-Contained Toolkit
tips.content: Use tools like Ventoy or GRUB2 to bundle multiple rescue ISOs, documentation, and apps onto a single USB drive.

tips.title: Mirror What You Rely On
tips.content: Sync copies of your most-used Linux repos, Flatpak apps, and docs using rsync for offline fallback or bandwidth-limited environments.

tips.title: Use Joplin with Local Sync
tips.content: You can run Joplin without cloud sync—use a shared folder or USB stick to move your notes between devices securely.

tips.title: Download Wikipedia with Kiwix
tips.content: Kiwix lets you download entire copies of Wikipedia or Wiktionary to a USB stick or internal drive—great for study or reference without Internet.

tips.title: Include System Repair Tools
tips.content: Don’t forget to add tools like GParted, Clonezilla, and SystemRescue to your offline kit for system emergencies.

tips.title: Store Digital Books Locally
tips.content: Use tools like Calibre to organize and read DRM-free eBooks offline. Works well with Project Gutenberg collections.
